repnme.cdata!:
Burkina Faso - National Environmental
            Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
While the second phase of the National
            Environmental Management Project is under preparation, the
            principal lessons to be drawn from the first phase of the
            project are as follows: 1) Attention must be given to
            ensuring that the community land management plan leads
            quickly to the assumption of responsibility by
            villages/communities. 2) Community organizations should be
            given greater responsibility and strengthened so that
            communities can establish their priorities not only by type
            of investment/activity, but also in relation to a budget
            determined at the outset. It is imperative for such a
            project to help beneficiaries put together the necessary
            information that will guarantee equal access to
            project-related benefits. 3) It is important to incorporate
            the financial dimension into the natural resource management
            approach, especially for those activities that generate
            revenue, and to strengthen the capabilities of target
            communities in their respect in order to create conditions
            conducive to the long-term sustainability of project
            investments. 4) Project activities must be planned in
            realistic way. Many of the delays affecting first-phase
            activities were traceable to cumbersome procedures. It is
            necessary to institute multi-year planning and start the
            preparation of bidding and pre-qualification documentation
            well before the effectiveness date.

NORWEGIAN GRANT FOR ENVIRONMENT-SOR,TF031310-BURKINA FASO - ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT,TF021460-VILLAGE LAND DEVELOPMENT PROJECT,TF021525-ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT PROJECT,TF031791-AFRICA - ENVIRONMENT MAINTENANCE,TF028001-FAC CONSULTANT TRUST FUND,TF026105-SAHELIAN NATURAL RESOURCE MGT SUPPORT
18153932.majtheme: Environment and natural resource management,Rural development,Social dev/gender/inclusion

abstracts.cdata!:
The project objectives are to stop and
            reverse the process of natural resources degradation in
            order to secure sustainable agricultural growth, to restore
            biodiversity, and to manage forests and wildlife
            sustainably. Attainment of these objectives will be sought
            through design and implementation of community land
            management plans, using an innovative participatory and
            holistic approach that has been tested and developed in
            about 20 pilot operations initiated in the last five years.
            The project consists of:  (a) design and implementation of
            community land management plans for 120 rural communities in
            three provinces; (b) design and implementation of combined
            forest and community land management plans for 47
            communities and three protected forests in two provinces;
            (c) technical support to existing operations in 18
            provinces; (d) establishment of national environmental and
            project impact monitoring systems; (e) development of human
            resources; and (f) management and studies.
